title.narrative: SMALL TOWNS Water, Sanitation, and Hygiene (WASH)

description.narrative: In small towns, at least 100,000 new users, prioritising vulnerable groups, use safe water and 100,000 use safe sanitation and improved hygiene practices, which contributes to Sanitation, Wash â€“ General, Water, Water Supply. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Advocacy And Public Engagement, Developing And Leveraging Resources And Partnerships, Operational Support To Programme Delivery, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: Vulnerable populations in rural and peri-urban areas have improved access to, and use of, safe and sustainable Water, Sanitation, and Hygiene (WASH) services.

sector.narrative: Sanitation - eliminating open defecation in peri-urban and urban communities
Sanitation - improving services in rural communities (except household water treatment and storage, moving up the ladder and strengthening sustainability)
Sanitation and hygiene - institutions (schools, health care facilities, ECD centres) including menstrual hygiene management
Water supply - peri-urban and urban communities service delivery

description.narrative: Water supply and Sanitation policy, planning and administration

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: In small towns, at least 100,000 new users, prioritising vulnerable groups, use safe water and 100,000 use safe sanitation andimproved hygiene practices

description.narrative: The small town programme continues to build on past successes with 4 towns in the process of upgrading WASH services. The implementation and management model is successful to date. A critical constraint is the depreciating Metical, which presents major contract management challenges to the infrastructure heavy project. | Status:Constrained | As-of Date:18/01/2017

title.narrative: of additional learners among vulnerable groups with access to and use of improved water and sanitation infrastructure in small towns.

actual.value: 2016:Cumulative for 2012-2016: 9,036 students2016 Only: 6,461 for Espungabera and Ulongue (2 schools)
